guideline: Adults aged 18–64 should perform at least 150–300 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic physical activity per week, or at least 75–150 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity.
source: World Health Organization (WHO) Global recommendations on Physical Activity for Health, 2020

guideline: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, while limiting saturated fats, trans fats, sodium, and added sugars, is associated with reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and certain cancers.
source: Dietary Guidelines for Americans 2020–2025, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

guideline: Adults should aim for 7–9 hours of quality sleep per night. Chronic sleep deprivation is linked to increased risk of obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and mental health disorders.
source: National Sleep Foundation Sleep Duration Recommendations, 2015; CDC Sleep and Health, 2022

guideline: Smoking cessation at any age is beneficial. Within 1 year of quitting, excess coronary heart disease risk is reduced by half. Within 15 years, cardiovascular risk approaches that of a non-smoker.
source: U.S. Surgeon General's Report on Smoking Cessation, 2020

guideline: Regular blood pressure monitoring is recommended for all adults. Hypertension (≥130/80 mmHg by AHA standards) significantly increases risk of stroke and heart disease. Lifestyle modifications include reducing sodium intake, increasing physical activity, and maintaining a healthy weight.

The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for colorectal cancer starting at age 45 for average-risk adults, using stool-based tests, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or colonoscopy.

Mental health and physical health are deeply interconnected. Chronic stress elevates cortisol levels and is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, immune dysfunction, and mental health disorders. Evidence-based stress management strategies include mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and regular physical exercise.
source: American Psychological Association (APA) Stress and Health, 2023; NIH MBSR Research

guideline: Excessive alcohol consumption increases risk of liver disease, certain cancers, and cardiovascular disease. The USPSTF recommends screening for unhealthy alcohol use in primary care. Low-risk drinking is defined as ≤1 drink/day for women and ≤2 drinks/day for men.
source: USPSTF Alcohol Misuse Screening and Counseling, 2018; NIAAA Guidelines

guideline: Maintaining a healthy body weight (BMI 18.5–24.9) and waist circumference (men <40 inches, women <35 inches) reduces risk of type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, sleep apnea, and certain cancers. Weight management is best achieved through a combination of diet, exercise, and behavioral support.
source: NIH Clinical Guidelines on the Identification, Evaluation, and Treatment of Overweight and Obesity in Adults, 1998 (updated 2023)

guideline: Adequate hydration (approximately 3.7 liters/day for men, 2.7 liters/day for women from all beverages and foods) supports kidney function, cognitive performance, and thermoregulation. These values vary based on activity level, climate, and health status.
source: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) Dietary Reference Intakes for Water, 2004

guideline: Preventive vaccinations across the lifespan significantly reduce morbidity and mortality. Adults should follow the CDC immunization schedule, including annual influenza vaccines, COVID-19 boosters, and Tdap, shingles (Shingrix), and pneumococcal vaccines at appropriate ages.

Social connection and strong relationships are associated with lower mortality risk. Loneliness and social isolation are linked to a 29% increased risk of heart disease and 32% increased risk of stroke. Community engagement and maintaining close relationships are evidence-based preventive health behaviors.
source: U.S. Surgeon General's Advisory on the Healing Effects of Social Connection, 2023
